tn.text: See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_poetry]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]]

The woman wishes that she could show her lover her affection in public as she could do her brother. She is not saying that a woman is allowed to make love with her brother. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
"you in public"
A woman would probably kiss her brother on his cheek in order to greet him.
"would make me feel ashamed"
The young woman continues to speak to her lover.

tn.ref: I would lead you and bring you into my mother's house
tn.text: If the lover were her brother, she could bring him to the family home. This was normal in that culture and is still today in some.

This could also be translated as "and she would teach me." Because the woman is inexperienced in making love, she is imagining that her lover or her mother would teach her how to make love. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: I would give you spiced wine to drink and some of the juice of my pomegranates
tn.text: The woman uses these images to say that she will give herself to her lover and make love with him. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"wine with spices" or "wine that has spices in it" This represents the intoxicating power of love-making. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
The woman represents her own sweet liquid with the extract of pomegranates. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
See how you translated "His left hand is under my head, and his right hand embraces me" in [[:en:bible:notes:sng:02:05|2:6]].
See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:sng:02:07|2:7]].

tn.ref: that you will ... until it is over
tn.text: See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:sng:02:07|2:7]].
Here begins Part Six of the book, the final part

tn.ref: Who is this who is coming up
tn.text: AT: "Look at this amazing woman as she comes up." See how you translated a similar phrase in [[:en:bible:notes:sng:06:10|6:10]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
"I woke you up" or "I aroused you"
See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:sng:02:03|2:3]].
under the apricot tree
"she bore you"
The young woman continues to speak to her lover.

tn.ref: Set me as a seal over your heart, like a seal on your arm
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) Because seals were very important, people kept them around their neck or on their hand constant. The woman wants to be with her lover constantly like a seal. or 2) A seal shows who owns the thing that has the seal on it. The woman wants herself as the seal on her lover's heart and arm to show that all of his thoughts, emotions, and actions belong to her. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

tn.ref: for love is as strong as death
tn.text: Death is very strong because it overcomes even the most powerful people of the world. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
"as tough as Sheol." Sheol never allows people to come back to life after they have already died. Love is as persistent as Sheol because it never changes. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

tn.ref: its flames burst out ... any other fire
tn.text: Love is very powerful like fire. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"burn suddenly"
The young woman continues to speak to her lover.
Love is so strong that it is like a fire that is so hot that it cannot be put out even with an ocean full of water. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"Oceans of water" or "Huge amounts of water"
"cannot extinguish" or "cannot put out"

tn.ref: nor can floods sweep it away
tn.text: Love never changes and always stays the same so it is like something that not even a powerful flood can move. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

In Israel, water from the rain flows into deep and narrow valleys. This creates a flood of water so powerful that it can move huge boulders and trees. Even today, floods sometimes sweep away very strong bridges.
"carry it away" or "wash it away"

tn.ref: If a man gave ... the offer would utterly be despised
tn.text: "Even if a man ... he would be utterly despised." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_hypo]])

tn.ref: all the possessions in his house
tn.text: "everything he owns"
"in order to get love" or "in order to buy love"

tn.ref: the offer would utterly be despised
tn.text: "people would completely despise him" or "people would harshly ridicule him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"young sister"

tn.ref: she will be promised in marriage
tn.text: AT: "a man comes and wants to marry her." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
The young woman's brothers continue to speak among themselves.

tn.ref: If she is a wall ... boards of cedar
tn.text: Because her breasts are small, she has a flat chest like a flat wall or a flat door. The brothers decide to give her decorations in order to help their sister look more beautiful. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"will decorate her"

tn.ref: my breasts are now like fortress towers
tn.text: The woman's breasts are tall like towers. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

tn.ref: so I am completely mature in his eyes
tn.text: Her beloved now sees that she is a fully-developed woman, and that pleases him. AT: "I am delightful to my beloved" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
Here "his eyes" refers to her lover. AT: "to him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
This is the name of a town in the northern part of Israel. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]]).
"rented out the vineyard"

tn.ref: to those who would maintain it
tn.text: "to people who would take care of it"

tn.ref: Each one was to bring a thousand shekels of silver for its fruit
tn.text: AT: "Each man was supposed to give Solomon a thousand shekels as payment for the fruit of the vineyard." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])

tn.ref: to bring a thousand shekels of silver
tn.text: "to bring 1,000 shekels of silver." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_bmoney]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])

tn.ref: My vineyard is my very own
tn.text: "I am in charge of my own vineyard." The woman refers to herself as a vineyard as in [[:en:bible:notes:sng:01:05|1:6]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: the thousand shekels belong to you, my dear Solomon
tn.text: The woman freely gives the profit of the vineyard to Solomon even though it belongs to her and she can give it to whomever she wants.
"to your voice"

tn.ref: let me be the one to hear it as well
tn.text: "let me hear it." The word "it" refers to the woman's voice.

tn.ref: be like a gazelle or a young stag
tn.text: See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:sng:02:16|2:17]].

"the mountains that have spices all over them." The woman uses this imagery to invite her lover to enjoy her. See how the lover uses the imagery of a mountain of myrrh and a hill of frankincense in [[:en:bible:notes:sng:04:06|4:6]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
